title: Set up Laravel to Deploy to Railway

i.c: Set up Laravel to Deploy to Railway

title: The previous local setup builds containers and work beautifully, but won’t work when deploying to Railway using GitHub integration.

i.c: local setup builds containers and work beautifully, but won
when deploying to Railway using GitHub integration.

title: Our endpoints work locally because Docker Compose builds all containers, networks them together, shares volumes, and sets up inter-container links and environment variables automatically. Railway does
not
b
support
docker-compose
c
and instead deploys a
single container per service
b

; it does not replicate your local multi-container orchestration unless you set up each container as a distinct Railway service and configure private networking. This is why your endpoint fails in Railway even though a service is deployed—the dependencies (PHP-FPM, DB, etc.) aren't available, or inter-service communication is broken.

i.c: locally because Docker Compose builds all containers,
networks them together, shares volumes, and sets up inter-container
it does not replicate your local multi-container orchestration unless
set up each container as a distinct Railway service and configure
private networking. This is why your endpoint fails in Railway even
though a service is deployed—the dependencies (PHP-FPM, DB, etc.) aren't
available, or inter-service communication is broken.

title.title: Docker based application cannot be redeployed successfully (502 Gateway Error)
title.description: Hello everybody, Since a month we have a issue with one specific service within our production environment. After the first request the deployed instance crashes. The instance is "just" a Java (Spring) application living inside a Docker container.  The codebase as the corresponding Dockerfile didn't changed.  ```dockerfile FROM maven:3-amazoncorretto-21 AS build COPY . /home/app RUN mvn -f /home/app/pom.xml clean package  FROM amazoncorretto:21 COPY --from=build /home/app/bot/target/bot-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar /usr/local/lib/stage.jar EXPOSE 8080 ENTRYPOINT ["java","-jar","/usr/local/lib/stage.jar", "--spring.profiles.active=prod"] ```  The `railway.json` file:  ```json {   "$schema": "https://railway.app/railway.schema.json",   "build": {     "builder": "DOCKERFILE"   } } ``` | Get Help with Railway

a.title: Docker based application cannot be redeployed successfully (502 Gateway Error)
a.description: Hello everybody, Since a month we have a issue with one specific service within our production environment. After the first request the deployed instance crashes. The instance is "just" a Java (Spring) application living inside a Docker container.  The codebase as the corresponding Dockerfile didn't changed.  ```dockerfile FROM maven:3-amazoncorretto-21 AS build COPY . /home/app RUN mvn -f /home/app/pom.xml clean package  FROM amazoncorretto:21 COPY --from=build /home/app/bot/target/bot-1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar /usr/local/lib/stage.jar EXPOSE 8080 ENTRYPOINT ["java","-jar","/usr/local/lib/stage.jar", "--spring.profiles.active=prod"] ```  The `railway.json` file:  ```json {   "$schema": "https://railway.app/railway.schema.json",   "build": {     "builder": "DOCKERFILE"   } } ``` | Get Help with Railway

title.title: nginx with php-fpm
title.description: Hi, I am trying to use nginx with fastcgi pass to a php-fpm service where my laravel app lives. In my local docker compose setup, I would simply set fastcgi_pass to where my Laravel container host is, e.g. fastcgi_pass ${APP_HOST}:9000;But on Railway, the nginx is giving me the error that the upstream(Laravel service) is timed out. I saw ipv6 address in the nginx error log about timed out that the APP_HOST must have converted so I guess it does find the correct host. However, with the correct host and port settings, somehow it time out and I have exhausted ways to find out what is happening under the hood. Does anyone have similar experience that can share with me how to deploy a php-fpm with nginx application? | Get Help with Railway

a.title: nginx with php-fpm
a.description: Hi, I am trying to use nginx with fastcgi pass to a php-fpm service where my laravel app lives. In my local docker compose setup, I would simply set fastcgi_pass to where my Laravel container host is, e.g. fastcgi_pass ${APP_HOST}:9000;But on Railway, the nginx is giving me the error that the upstream(Laravel service) is timed out. I saw ipv6 address in the nginx error log about timed out that the APP_HOST must have converted so I guess it does find the correct host. However, with the correct host and port settings, somehow it time out and I have exhausted ways to find out what is happening under the hood. Does anyone have similar experience that can share with me how to deploy a php-fpm with nginx application? | Get Help with Railway

can't find or reach supporting containers (like DB, PHP-FPM, queue
worker) because those aren't deployed.

each component is a separate service and linked by environment/hostname

title: This method organizes the one repo with multiple Docker containers into individual container images pushed independently, ready for multi-service deployment on Railway.Railway only deploys one container (one service) per deployment because it does not support docker-compose natively for multi-container apps. If your GitHub repo contains the full multi-container project, to deploy each container separately on Railway you must:

i.c: This method organizes the one repo with multiple Docker containers into individual container images pushed independently, ready for multi-service deployment on Railway.Railway only deploys one container (one service) per deployment because it does not support docker-compose natively for multi-container apps. If your GitHub repo contains the full multi-container project, to deploy each container separately on Railway you must:

title:
In GitHub Actions, create a workflow that builds and pushes each container image separately to a container registry (e.g. Docker Hub). Use Docker
build actions with different Dockerfiles or contexts.

i.c:
In GitHub Actions, create a workflow that builds and pushes each container image separately to a container registry (e.g. Docker Hub). Use Docker
build actions with different Dockerfiles or contexts.

title:
For example, use a matrix build to iterate over nginx, php-fpm, laravel,
react, and mysql containers, build each Docker image, and push it tagged separately.

i.c:
For example, use a matrix build to iterate over nginx, php-fpm, laravel,
react, and mysql containers, build each Docker image, and push it tagged separately.

title:
Then in Railway, create separate services for each container image,
configuring ports, environment variables, and start commands per
service.

i.c:
Then in Railway, create separate services for each container image,
configuring ports, environment variables, and start commands per
service.

title: This way, your single GitHub repo hosts all container sources, but containers are built and pushed independently, and Railway deploys each as a distinct service. Otherwise, Railway tries to deploy one container per service and cannot natively handle the whole compose stack at once.

i.c: This way, your single GitHub repo hosts all container sources, but containers are built and pushed independently, and Railway deploys each as a distinct service. Otherwise, Railway tries to deploy one container per service and cannot natively handle the whole compose stack at once.

title: 6-1. Use GitHub Actions with a matrix or multiple jobs:
b
h
purple

i.c: 1. Use GitHub Actions with a matrix or multiple jobs:

title: Define a GitHub Actions workflow in
.github/workflows/main.yml
c

i.c: Define a GitHub Actions workflow in

title: Use separate build and push steps for each container in your project (nginx, php-fpm, laravel, react, mysql).

i.c: Use separate build and push steps for each container in your project (nginx, php-fpm, laravel, react, mysql).

title: You can specify different Dockerfiles or context folders for each container.

i.c: You can specify different Dockerfiles or context folders for each container.

title: Use a matrix build to run these builds in parallel efficiently.

i.c: Use a matrix build to run these builds in parallel efficiently.

title:
textname: Build and Push Docker Images

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        service: [nginx, php-fpm, laravel, react, mysql]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Build and push ${{ matrix.service }} image
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v4
        with:
          context: ./path/to/${{ matrix.service }}
          file: ./path/to/${{ matrix.service }}/Dockerfile
          push: true
          tags: your-dockerhub-username/${{ matrix.service }}:latest

i.c:
textname: Build and Push Docker Images

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        service: [nginx, php-fpm, laravel, react, mysql]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Build and push ${{ matrix.service }} image
        uses: docker/build-push-action@v4
        with:
          context: ./path/to/${{ matrix.service }}
          file: ./path/to/${{ matrix.service }}/Dockerfile
          push: true
          tags: your-dockerhub-username/${{ matrix.service }}:latest

title: The action will push each container image separately to your Docker registry.

i.c: The action will push each container image separately to your Docker registry.

title: Once the above is configured, push to GitHub.

i.c: Once the above is configured, push to GitHub.

title: Each Railway service builds and deploys independently but shares the repo as source, building from their respective Dockerfiles.

i.c: Each Railway service builds and deploys independently but shares the repo as source, building from their respective Dockerfiles.

title: Railway will handle builds and deployments for each service separately.

i.c: Railway will handle builds and deployments for each service separately.

title: This approach avoids mixing all containers in a single Railway deployment, opts for individual services with clear isolated build contexts, and uses Railway’s private networking and variable referencing for intra-service communication.

i.c: approach avoids mixing all containers in a single Railway deployment,
opts for individual services with clear isolated build contexts, and
uses Railway’s private networking and variable referencing for

title: It allows you to keep developing locally using your current docker-compose stack, while enabling seamless multi-service deployment on Railway via one GitHub repo source without extra pipelines.

i.c: allows you to keep developing locally using your current docker-compose
stack, while enabling seamless multi-service deployment on Railway via
one GitHub repo source without extra pipelines.
